@markusthoemmes It's working now. I did the following on my host: 

```
sudo visudo -f /etc/sudoers.d/vagrant
```
Then added this lines to the file: 
```
vagrant ALL=NOPASSWD:ALL
Defaults:vagrant !requiretty
```
And now it's working again. 

Beside that I used the companies VPN tunnel. Might be that it also counts to the solution, as there are some proxies involved here in the network.

But for example, if we configure the port as `4369` on first node and `4370` for second node, first node will try to find other node using `4369` port but on second node, only `4370` is opened, so look-up will fail.

I am looking for the configuration to segregate its binding port(`4369`) and communication port(`4370`). But I am not sure it is feasible.

The indirection is dangerous here since you can end up affecting the setting for a majority of actions unintentially. Did you consider factoring out the prewarm kind(s) to ansible instead?

It seems, all Erlang nodes must use same epmd port.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40189097/erlang-epmd-connects-to-other-host-with-non-default-epmd-port

It means, we cannot run a couchdb cluster on a single machine.

As of now I am trying the following scenario.

1. use same epmd port(`4369`) for all couchdb nodes.
2. do not map that port to host (remove `-p 4369:4369`).
3. trying to form a cluster.

Since both nodes will be running on a single machine, they will be in the same subnet.
They might be able to communicate with each other using their container IPs.

So though port is not opened in host layer, they may be able to connect to other node using `172.17.0.2:4369`.
For this, when we deploy couchdb, we need to specify its container IPs.
(currently, we are specifying host IP).

Since it assumes nodes are running on same subnet, it won't work on distributed environments.
So we need to differentiate local deployment with distributed deployment.


Is it worth to take this approach?

Just thinking out loud:

Most users in the community using new docker (Docker for mac) are using newest Docker version (17.x) as it's easier to get the latest version the Docker for Mac auto updates.

For docker-machine is easier to install old version and keep it isolated via vm name `whisk` from the other development activities outside Whisk that an user will do in his computer.

In addition Docker for mac is kind of broken because runc is not possible because the hardcoded version in the invoker Docker file.

If we want to attract more community help we need to make it much easier to get their computer working out of the box, also most of the work people are contributing are not specific to having docker 1.12 installed.

I propose 3 things to compromise:
1. Have docker-machine with runc enable by default, assume for the most part people are using 1.12 
   Doc if user is using newer version of docker they need to disable runc via file or ansible override
2. Have Docker for Mac with runc always disable 
3. At some point we need to look into upgrading the version of docker we support, the more we wait more painful will be to upgrade, as more and more users in the wild will be using latest version when deploying
A previous pr added: `group_vars/all:  useRunc: "{{ invoker_use_runc | default(true) }}"` which satisfies 1 but does not work for docker-for-mac (2) because it shares the `local` environment.

# About latency from replication factor

To state the simple conclusion first, **there's no additional latency by setting replication factor in current openwhisk system.** Because current KafkaProducerConnector sets 'ACKS_CONFIG(acks)' as 1 which means that leader of kafka responds ack to client after write the record to its local log but without awaiting full acks from other followers. You can find the details on [Kafka Docs](https://kafka.apache.org/documentation/)
By the way, it could lead to lose some messages if leader of kafka fails before copying data to the followers.

If we want to get more guarantee that there's no message lose after receiving ack, we can set 'ACKS_CONFIG' to "all" which means leader of kafka responds message after finishing replication.
I changed 'ACKS_CONFIG" to "all" and roughly checked latency of producing message by getting duration between the "posting topic ... " log and "posted to ..." log. I ignored that first 20 logs because there's some latency of kafka warm-up. Here's the result.

- RF: 1 (ack = 1)
> min: less than 1ms
   avg: 0.4 ms
   max: 4.0 ms

- RF: 1 (ack = all)
> min: less than 1ms
   avg: 3.6 ms
   max: 25.0 ms

- RF: 2 (ack = all)
> min: less than 1ms
   avg: 10.4 ms
   max: 52.0 ms

- RF: 3 (ack = all)
> min: less than 1ms
   avg: 14.4ms
   max: 87.0ms

we can find that "ack=all" increase latency even in case of RF=1. Maybe we need to provide config to set ACKS_CONFIG value.

@devbv many thanks for the update on the review comments and the investigation on latency. I think what you described makes perfect sense and making the ACKS_CONFIG value configurable per environment is the right thing to do.

I've done some tests on latency and load of the overall system as well and was not possible to detect a regression. I've tested maximum throughput with a single user/action and with 100 different users. Further checked on latency for different runtimes. All numbers in the same ballpark.

Further I've performed some investigations on resiliency under load and found that even with `acks=1` the loss during the outage of a single node seems acceptable. 

Since OW is latency sensitive I would vote to go with `acks=1` as default and allow a "deployer" to override the default per deployment. We might need a comment on the setting to describe the tradeoff.

you control the limits per deployment - there are three limits to be aware of: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all#L102-L107
1. actions per minute per namespace
1. concurrent actions live at any given time per namespace
1. total concurrent actions in the system

so if you are tuning for 1M/s for the entire system vs a specific namespace, you'll need to adjust the limits accordingly.

the other knob you want to control is how many container to run per invoker vm:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all#L163-L164
as the higher the container count per vm the fewer vms you need

you might also want to look at work from @tysonnorris to increase intra-container concurrency so you can run more functions inside a single container at the same time which could also reduce the invoker count.

As @perryibm noted in #2569 the other parameters to take into account is the expected execution time of the actions.

A semantic change could be observed here - if an image is removed from docker hub, the pull will fail. However the action will continue to run in a particular invoker which has a previously pulled image, until that image is purged locally. This is a new behavior. 

We should separate the convenience of local development from resilience to network partitions. An option for the former is to restore an implicit pull bypass if the image prefix matches the local registry prefix. This could be done with a feature toggle through ansible as well for added control.
